3.2. Model Validation by Ground Truth Data
The model prediction results were validated by the ground truth data in China. The sensitivity
and specificity of model prediction were 0.78 and 0.89, respectively. The total prediction match rate
Three schistosome species pose the main infection risk for humans.
schistosome species in China, the Philippines and three closely situated small foci in Celebes,
snails, whose latitudinal movements over land during
most of the last million years may have been prevented by the development of the Himalaya plateau
overlap to a great extent on
the African continent and in the Middle East, but not everywhere. The former, the most abundant of
the schistosome species, has also found an exclusive niche in the Northeast part of South America
and on some of the Caribbean islands but are now disappearing from the latter, however this is not
due to climate change [29]. Its distribution is supported by the broad geographic range of
spp. snails that serve as obligatory hosts for its larval stages. Recently, however,
identified in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and Shenzhen City in the Guangdong
Province of China and has remained there since the 1970s [30], a fact that could eventually result in
and the Middle East due to its reliance on
spp. intermediate snail hosts [31]. Although this
schistosome species must also have been brought from Africa to Latin America during the slave trade
became established there because of the absence of
snails. Although this information indicates that schistosome species and their specific snails
can spread into various new areas, this is not of a magnitude that requires it to be considered when
discussing the risk for schistosomiasis due to temperature augmentation.
To assess the potential impact of climate change on the transmission of schistosomiasis in the
world we developed a biological model using available data from the literature. Compared to
required less total heat energy to complete one
generation [17,25,26]. Therefore, the transmission intensity of the two latter species

snails, whose latitudinal movements over land during most of the
